original: Avassutāya bhikkhuniyā avassutassa purisapuggalassa kāyasaṁsaggaṁ sādiyantiyā āpattiyo channaṁ āpattisamuṭṭhānānaṁ katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti?
analyzed: avassutāya bhikkhuniyāḥ avassutassa purisa puggalassa kāya sasaggam sādiyantiyāḥ āpattiyaḥ channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti
translated: When it comes to the offenses for a lustful nun consenting to a lustful man making physical contact with her, through how many of the six kinds of origins of offenses do they originate?

original: Avassutāya bhikkhuniyā avassutassa purisapuggalassa kāyasaṁsaggaṁ sādiyantiyā āpattiyo channaṁ āpattisamuṭṭhānānaṁ ekena samuṭṭhānena samuṭṭhanti—
analyzed: avassutāya bhikkhuniyāḥ avassutassa purisa puggalassa kāya sasaggam sādiyantiyāḥ āpattiyaḥ channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam ekena samuṭṭhānena samuṭṭhanti

original: kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti, na vācato …pe….🔽Dadhiṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjantiyā āpattiyo channaṁ āpattisamuṭṭhānānaṁ katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti?
analyzed: kāyataḥ ca cittataḥ ca samuṭṭhanti na vācataḥ pe  dadhim viññāpetvā bhuñjantiyāḥ āpattiyaḥ channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti
translated: through body and mind, not through speech. …🔽When it comes to the offenses for asking for curd and then eating it, through how many of the six kinds of origins of offenses do they originate?

original: Dadhiṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjantiyā āpattiyo channaṁ āpattisamuṭṭhānānaṁ catūhi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti—🔽siyā kāyato samuṭṭhanti, na vācato na cittato;
analyzed: dadhim viññāpetvā bhuñjantiyāḥ āpattiyaḥ channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam catūhi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti  siyā kāyataḥ samuṭṭhanti na vācataḥ na cittataḥ
translated: They originate in four ways:🔽they may originate from body and mind, not from speech;

original: siyā kāyato ca vācato ca samuṭṭhanti, na cittato;
analyzed: siyā kāyataḥ ca vācataḥ ca samuṭṭhanti na cittataḥ
translated: they may originate from body and speech and mind, not from speech;

original: siyā kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti, na vācato;
analyzed: siyā kāyataḥ ca cittataḥ ca samuṭṭhanti na vācataḥ
translated: they may originate from body and mind, not from speech;

original: siyā kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.
analyzed: siyā kāyataḥ ca vācataḥ ca cittataḥ ca samuṭṭhanti
translated: they may originate from body and speech and mind.
The fifth section on origin is finished.
